Authors:
Vladimir Mikryukov, Elena N. Bilanenko, Natalya I
Bondarenko, Denis V Goryunov, Maria D Logacheva, Kirill V. Mikhailov,
Irina Milyutina, Alexaned P Mylnikov, Vladimir E Fedosov, Leonid Rusin,
Sergey A Spirin, Vladimir V. Aleoshin
Title:
Unexpected diversity of early-diverging Holomycota in deep
horizons of a boreal peatland
Keywords:
fungi; diversity; Holomycota; Microsporidia; oxygen
deficiency; peatland; Rozellomycota
Abstract:
Deep horizons of boreal peatlands are cold, organic-rich,
acidic, and oxygen deficient. They potentially contain unique,
extremotolerant biota, which cannot be detected with nonsequence-based
methods. Using high-throughput sequencing of highly variable domains of
the 18S rRNA gene we investigated Holomycota communities associated with
organic matter and pore water in oxygen-depleted horizons of a boreal
peatland. To avoid taxonomic bias, we targeted the entire Opisthokonta
using different DNA extraction kits, polymerases, and primers with wide
taxonomic coverage. We identified novel lineages of early-diverging
Holomycota and support the lineages recently anticipated in other
research. Many of the identified taxa are unicellular and
extremotolerant Eumycota, including ecologically specific
representatives of Neocallimastigomycota and Wallemiomycetes.
Rozellomycota (known as Rozellida, Cryptomycota, and Microsporidia) were
represented by all major clades, except for putatively marine lineages,
illustrating that deep oxygen-depleted horizons of boreal peatland serve
as repositories of early-diverging Holomycota species. Rozellomycota
sequences accounted for 25Â–80% of the Holomycota sequences, suggesting
that this group may contribute a lot into fungal communities functioning
in peatlands.
